item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

This is a proper example. By the way, in the future, avoid infinite loops.

[code]import java.util.List;
import java.util.ArrayList;

public class Highscores {
public static void main(String[] args) {
int attack = 1, defense = 1, strength = 1, hits = 1;
List list = new ArrayList();
while (true) {
list.clear();
list.add(“Attack:” + attack + ", Defense: " + defense + ", Strength: " + strength + " and Hits: " + hits);
}
}
}[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

You’re not clearing the list in the loop, so it’s going to run out of memory. What is with the infinite loop? They just cause problems unless you know what you’re doing.

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Should I change to a different Java version then?

Learn proper design techniques, get some common sense, take a class, etc. All better suggestions. There is nothing wrong on Oracle’s end, so design your program better. Updating/downgrading won’t fix anything

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

It’s not a bug, and updating java won’t do a thing. Your constantly using memory by repeating the task and not releasing it at all. You’re going to need to clear the list on every repetition, or when it reaches a certain number of items, clear it.

@HcoJusin - My bad, got mixed up (i’m a bit rusty at java).

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

dain bramage:

A standard java application is only allowed to use 2GB or memory (on default), and simply, you’re using it up by repeating the addition of adding the new items onto the list.

The default heap size is 128MB, where did you get 2GB???

Where do I report the Java bug to Sun?

It’s not a java bug, but a flaw in your program. A small size doesn’t mean it’s error free.

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @dain_bramage dain bramage
item.description:
@dain_bramage wrote:

A standard java application is only allowed to use 2GB or memory (on default), and simply, you’re using it up by repeating the addition of adding the new items onto the list.

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

The problem is that you are never declaring it to false after inputting the data. It keeps adding the exact same data into the list, thus running you out of memory.

@HcoJustin - Damn, beat me to it lol

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

You’re continuously adding to the list, causing it to expand, and eventually you will run out of memory if it’s not limited… Have you checked to see when it runs out of memory? (how many elements?) Under normal circumstances that shouldn’t happen

Read full topic

item.title: Java problem
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

I’m making a new standalone highscores application and it’s going well so far although it’s in early stages but I’m coming across a weird error. The code is really small and it runs good for a while so I think it’s a Java bug. I’ve updated to the latest version but the bug is still there. Has anyone ever successfully reported a bug to Sun before?

Here’s the error:

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space at java.util.Arrays.copyOf(Unknown Source) at java.lang.AbstractStringBuilder.expandCapacity(Unknown Source) at java.lang.AbstractStringBuilder.append(Unknown Source) at java.lang.StringBuilder.append(Unknown Source) at Highscores.main(Highscores.java:9)

Here’s the sauce:

[code=java5]import java.util.List;
import java.util.ArrayList;

public class Highscores {
public static void main(String[] args) {
int attack = 1, defense = 1, strength = 1, hits = 1;
List list = new ArrayList();
while (true) {
list.add(“Attack:” + attack + ", Defense: " + defense + ", Strength: " + strength + " and Hits: " + hits);
}
}
}[/code]

Read full topic
